Combining Clojure and ClojureScript Libraries - Part 2: Set Up Your Base Project

08 Feb 2014

Seting Up You Base Project:

A Sample Base Project is available if you would like to use it. It already has Speclj installed and running for both Clojure and ClojureScript. We will be referencing this project throught this tutorial.

Regardless of whether you use the sample project, you project structure should look similar. This is especially true in how your src/ and spec/ paths should looks. You'll want a structure like src/file-type/project-name/code.file-type. For example, in the sample project we have src/clj/myproject/core.clj for Clojure source and src/cljs/myproject/core.cljs for the ClojureScript source.

A similar structure should be used for your tests.

myproject
   |
   |--- test
   |     |--- clj
   |     |    |--- myproject
   |     |            |--- test-code.clj
   |     |--- cljs
   |           |--- myproject
   |                   |--- test-code.cljs
   |--- src
   |     |--- clj
   |     |     |--- myproject
   |     |             |--- source-code.clj
   |     |--- cljs
   |          |--- myproject
                       |--- source-code.cljs

Where We Are

We now have a base project template that can be used to get a sense of the structure of our project, but that's about it. In Part 3 of this tutorial we'll use profiles separate our Clojure and ClojureScript classpaths.
